column93:
We're interested to learn about your music earnings before online music streaming became widespread (2015).



In our study, we use the year 2015 as the tipping point for audio streaming becoming mainstream because: 2015 was the first year since 2001 that the international recording industry reported annual sectoral growth and also the first year that digital revenue overtook revenue from physical formats. In addition to this, 2015 was the first year that audio subscription streaming accounted for more than 20% of the UK market for recorded music.



 Did you earn money from your music prior to this time?

column193:
The section about how much money have you made "personally" before tax could be re-configured perhaps.

Myself and many other UK musicians will own our rights and process income through limited companies. In any tax year, it is those companies which receive money, and hopefully hold on to it. Because I have a mortgage, and I don't need to prove my income to my mortgage provider any longer, I take the bare minimum of money out of my businesses. Some years it's as little as 12k, and I pay no tax.
Without a follow up question about these structures, someone like myself who was trying to be precise would not end up describing the actual amount I make, or HOW it ends up supporting me.

There could also be a section which explores how visibility due to releases can generate other income. For some of us, releases have been reduced to a kind of calling card, or reminder to the marketplace that we are here. While we know we may not make significant income from streaming, it leads to an uplift in many other career areas, such as brand endorsement, private parties for corporate or institutional bodies, or lucrative performance fees. 

It would be worth looking at this document which really breaks down what all of those micro streams may be:

http://money.futureofmusic.org/40-revenue-streams/?fbclid=IwAR2x4Lq7YfNSgUFUuP9X5eHqD1oJDY-rJw-FKxsW3yayzBCduXtO-zg26MY

A significant streaming income seems to be an elusive jewel.

column193: They (streaming services) have been getting away with unethically low royalty fees for too long. It can't help but feel like a very aware process of exploitation of the artist (and contributors to musical output), as well as hurting audience's connection music as a product (and how they invest in it). Content is coming too free and easy which is harming people who work in the industry and contribute so greatly to it. The excuse streaming platforms give for low rates is that artists earn incomes from various other places, with their services acting as signposts to and encourage fanbase growth and exposure. The truth is that musicians, even at a very high level, are struggling to cover living costs in their day-to-day, despite working incredibly (often detrimentally) hard. This has to stop.

column193: There is very little transparency in how the royalties are distributed, and especially how licensing fees of live streamed performances are collected and distributed. There is very little engagement from our CMO and from what little I know, they take more care in allocating royalties and licencing fees to large publishers than engage with the majority of their members. The current royalties and licencing system is horrifically broken, opaque to outsiders and entirely geared toward delivering the majority of revenue share to themselves and large industry organisations.

I earn almost nothing from streaming (really)  and feel that streaming platforms favour a certain audience and ignore my genre. Only when people search for my material would they be exposed to it. 
I have a distrust in the reporting and revenue shares are minuscule and also subject to complicated US tax. It's difficult as an independent artists to keep all these platforms 'watered' to manipulate algorithms when i don't ave time. I want to learn and create, not be a digital marketer never off social media. I have a life and family to juggle too.

column193: I honestly scratch my head about Spotify... I have had 5 top 40 records and I can say I have NEVER received any significant royalties. I have tried to check, looking at the Warner chapel statement which is the size of the yellow pages, it's often about 15£ in total every 6 months. I rely completely on sync and advertising sync fees. Sometimes I wonder how I make any money at all, we used to get about 3k per quarter if a song was play listed on radio 1 - now I ignore the royalty statements as they are just peanuts. I really only survive on sync, with film or TV. God help the future young musicians.

column193:
I am always amazed at how little I get to record and produce my music. All the streaming platforms need artists but don't want to pay us, for the work that we produce. If I was a doctor or a nurse everyone would be shouting how bad this is. However, when it comes to music no one says anything. 
If you are an independent artist you carry all the cost, but I if don't create music then I would find it hard to get work, plus most promoters will ask for your link to one of the streaming. Whatever way you look at it. Artist loses, why because just like everyone else we love the work that we do... However, we still have the rent/mortgage and all the other bills just like everyone else. Sad really

1. Independent artists are powerless to understand or negotiate the revenue provided to them by streaming services. 
2. This sector appears not to be regulated effectively.
3. If a stream was anywhere near a download in terms of revenue for the independent artist, our income from streaming would be 100 times greater.
4. It is good that Parliament has been paying attention to this recently.

Prior to 2018 I worked full time in music split between the UK, France and Caribbean. 
I happened to start a PhD in a more toward academic work in the last 1/4 of 2019, so my life in music has significantly changed. I have however been involved in public ally funded projects to create and perform music in the past 18months and although almost all performance work has stopped I continue to earn almost all of my income from teaching music.

column193:
streaming is an utter waste of time as regards trying to make a living out of it from music. I took virtually everything off Spotify and only left one compilation as a 'sampler'.

The only people who seem to like it are unknown bands who are just happy to get someone/anyone listening to their music, and huge bands that generate a bit more cash.
If you do not have another significant income source [ie - gigs.cds. t.shirts] you will not make a career in music from streaming. Period.

column193:
Yes, there is actually. 

I am a 36 year old musician with A* GCSE Music, an A in A-level Music and I went on to get my degree in Music from the Guitar Institute in London. The popularity of streaming with non-musicians or 'consumers' is MORE THAN WORRYING. In no other industry are you expected to work your arse off, for free, sometimes at cost, for many years just to be told you shouldn't expect to make any money from your work: you should just be happy to put it out there. You can, however, expect to sell a t-shirt with your logo on it for 250% the price of an album, and in all likelihood you will sell more of those. I'm sorry, but NO. 

I have spent the last 7 years perfecting the arrangements, mix, master and artwork for my album and I am now £30,000 in debt. All this is highly skilled work. I did my first ever recording on a Tascam 4-track tape machine when I was 11. I used those recordings for my GCSE compositions. Now, I have a Twitch channel where I stream various performance videos and anything music-related I have, to gain exposure, so I am now thinking like someone who owns a TV channel. My point here is that I have acquired so many new skills in recent times that are so far removed from practicing my instrument and voice/writing songs that it makes it even worse to think how highly skilled I am but to feel confident that I will be destined to house-share, renting for the foreseeable future. My brother is fine, he chose the right job, he paid his 15 year mortgage off in 8 years. I may never get on the property ladder. Am I any less skilled than him? Are musical skills any less important than putting someone to sleep and keeping them asleep until the operation is over? After all, we both perform in theatres. And in my brother's own words, being an anaesthetist is a lot like being the bass player in the band - no one notices a good one but you sure as hell notice a crap one. (My brother also plays guitar, sings and records music/videos for his church services)

It is not fair to expect us musicians, or 'farmers' to produce our own content at our own expense, and then let the consumers consume it for free. I have come close many times to thinking F this, if someone as highly qualified and experienced as myself, who spent his entire life dedicated to music, can't see a way to earn any money, then what hope has anyone else got? 

Pre-Covid I was out performing at weddings at least twice every week, honing my skills, perfecting my craft, whilst recording my album and teaching guitar in the midweek. Sustaining myself and saving up for the album 100% from music. I did some research. To put on a basic 10-date mini tour I would need at least £8000. (per show = £150 per man, £100 hotels + £100 petrol). Do you know how many people would need to stream my entire album on Spotify to earn this? I'll tell you. The answer is 1.7 million people. Even at £10 per cd I would have made £17,000,000! So, can you tell me why anybody in their right mind would be happy about streaming? Apart from the consumers, obviously. It's great for them - free music - skip if you don't like it - this then creates laziness and there are podcasts on YouTube that have discussed this already - Spotify listeners have much less patience than CD or vinyl (album) fans. If it's not good in the first ten seconds - SKIP - that's why some musicians will 'play up to the platform' and sacrifice a long intro, one such as Shine On You Crazy Diamond by Pink Floyd, in favour of simply counting 4 in and you're in (Happy - Pharrell). This is not good long term. I have spoken with many guests at weddings and in pubs when I'm playing - most people WANT to support musicians, but when everything is there for free, why would you bother? Well, because people like me will put our guitars down and start investing in Bitcoin instead. Or go and get a job at Tesco. Covid has proved supermarket workers are essential. Music has been bounded around as being essential for mental well-being but I don't feel anywhere near as valued as my dad, a supermarket worker, or my bigger brother, a consultant anaesthesiologist. At least with the Bitcoin route, it is my own fault if I lose it all.

The way I see it (and Elton John too it seems), in 20-30 years' time, we will still be performing songs from the 'golden decades' of music (1950-2005 ish) at weddings/parties, and they will have sailed off into the distance and we won't realise until its way too late that there isn't actually anyone bothered about being a pop or rock star anymore because we all accept no one actually makes any money from it, so just open an Only Fans account instead. A 'singer' I follow on Twitch (I use the term singer loosely) has 2 songs of her band on Spotify. The most played one has 200,000 listens. She regularly has 6000+ people watching her livestream in her underwear, and this happens most days. I am annoyed by her but I also feel for her. She thinks this is just what you have to do to get your music out there. Surely?

The music industry is a joke in its current state and streaming has made it better for consumers and worse for creators. They say hate the game don't hate the players. Quite.

column193:
In the 'years you were less active than 2020', there is no option to not select a year, so I selected 1991, which is the year I was born. I was not really active until 2014, even then I was more active than in 2020.

Streaming royalties, for the majority of improvising/'DIY' musicians are very very small. I've made less than a few euros every year from streaming. Streaming has damaged live music an album sales in this sector very badly.

column193: Except for the very few who have the right contacts or backing from wealthy parents, music as a way of making a living is dead. People expect and can get to listen music for free on demand and thanks to universities offering performing arts degrees, there is a glut of performers/creators. Despite having previous success (sold 1.5 million back in 2011), I'm now in the process of changing career. If you have any openings for an enthusiastic and driven data scientist please let me know!

column193:
I have released less original music over the last few years so expected a decline in direct income from it across the board, including from streaming.  That said, streaming has kept my music available where it has been taken off the shelves in other formats.

In the same period, the impact of the streaming market has been incredibly significant to my profile, so whilst I do not make vast sums directly from streaming, my overall earnings have more than doubled and my profile / career sustainability is higher than ever due to my ability to leverage the presence and credibility of my work on streaming platforms.

I have a couple of tracks out on Spotify, and am in the process of releasing my first portrait album, but the money I receive from streaming royalties is negligible (not even 50p)

column193:
As someone who sits on both the master and the songwriting/publishing side of the fence (in terms of revenue from streaming and other sources), and who self-funds the recording and promotion of my music, I strongly disagree that songwriters/publishers should get a larger share of the revenue from streaming (and other sources), as they are pushing for at the moment.

I, as the record label for my own recordings, am taking all the financial risk. For example, my last album "Goodbye Butterfly" cost over £100K not including VAT to have recorded and promoted. The co-writer I worked with (and his publisher) for this album, didn't contribute to this cost at all, and neither did my publisher. The money came entirely out of my own pocket. It is therefore surely reasonable and fair that I should retain by far the largest share of the revenue generated by my music, and my belief that the current ratio of split between master & publishing revenue is correct and justified.

If you look at all business models within and outside of the music industry, it is always the person or company who fronts up the capital to invest that retains the lions share of the profits (if any). This is a standard business model, and is entirely logical and fair, so why should the music industry model be any different?

My opinion is that if songwriters and publishers want a larger share of the revenue pie, then they should have to contribute to the costs of recording and promoting music proportionately to the record labels / independent artists, i.e. if costs are shared 50/50 between the [songwriters/publishers] & the [record labels/independent artists], then profits should also be split 50/50 between those parties. THAT would be fair. Likewise if the costs were shared 60/40 in the aforementioned example, then profits should be split in the same ratio. 

However, the current situation is that songwriters and publishers don't contribute to the costs of recording and promoting music at all, but they still get a substantial portion of the revenue. Nobody has an issue with this, including myself, as everybody recognises the value of a composition and feels that that should be rewarded financially. But to ask for a larger share than what they're currently receiving, still without contributing to the costs, is blatantly unfair in my opinion.

column193:
The biggest problem with streaming is the royalty rates and recoupment process on standard industry deals. Our major label releases have 165 million streams between them on Spotify which is apparently worth somewhere around £550k. But since our royalty rate is 18%, we would have only chipped off somewhere around £100k's worth of debt while the label has pocketed the other £450k. 

At this point we have most likely generated enough income to equal the money they spent on us but according to our latest statement we are still £500k in the red. We will need to generate a further £2.5 million in order to pay this off and receive £1 in royalties.

column193:
Streaming revenue is not transparent. There are multiple 'Spotify Royalty' calculators online, all of which bear no resemblance to actual revenue generated. E.g. my track at 53k plays should earn £182.32 according to Music Gateway, when in reality my distributor has received a total of £34.88

Streaming is not a sustainable income for independent artists.

column193:
I release music in a very niche genre. I have self-released all of my albums, at first distributed through Pinnacle, then distributed by Universal for a period, and finally I moved everything to solely on my own website that I built plus an Amazon seller account. I have seen some drop off in sales (similar to all physical formats I think), but my existing audience are quite loyal and keeping more of the gross on each copy has more than made up for missing out on the casual sales I would have got from being stocked in record shops. 

At the same time, when I took all physical distribution in-house I also signed a digital distribution deal with AWAL so my music is on all the streaming and download services. 

This combination has worked well, but my digital income has never risen above a small fraction of the income from direct sales of CDs and Vinyl, despite being heard by thousands of times more people. To give some indication, I generally sell around 4-6000 CDs of each album at £10 each, of which I'm keeping about 85%. My most-played songs on Spotify are at 81,000, 64,000 and 61,000 streams each. Not huge in the grand scheme of things, and I can philosophise it as the start of a pipeline that converts listeners to buying gig tickets or direct downloads, but still not generating enough in actual royalties to really make a difference to my finances. 

I need to maintain the physical media sales to survive. I'm lucky to be in a genre where CDs are still a big thing, and I do very well out of sales at the merch desk at shows (another reason the lack of gigs in 2020 hit me hard!). But if the last physical sales slip and are replaced by streaming then I won't be able to carry on. I'd love digital sales to be the future for ecological reasons - I feel awful posting out chunks of plastic and cardboard around the world every day - but I can't see how the money from it will be fixed enough to allow a career for people like me.

column193:
Tiktok - (and other platforms similar services like insta reels)
Allows people to build brands using musicians music for free.
Tiktok are essentially a broadcaster ... like SKY TV.
Tiktok users are essentially the shows, and like shows on TV they should license the music they use and not be allowed to use it for free. 
Tiktok should also have licenses in place with PROs and pay performance royalties just like tv via PRS.
Instead tiktok has got away with being a music streaming service like Spotify, when it is anything but.
They don't even pay per stream, but per usage, I've personally had over 50million streams on tiktok and received around £200.


Online Advertising - royalties 
When a brand pays for advertising space on tv composers and publishers are paid royalties for every play. When a brand pays Facebook or YouTube for advertising space ... where are the royalties? There aren't any. The shift to online advertising has been rather rapid as brands realise it is more effective than tv. When brands no longer advertise on tv there will be no royalties. This needs to be fixed. 


Tiktok commercial library
Tracks are licensed under blanket deals with library owners/rightsholders. composers do not know the terms of these deals. Tiktok pay library a fee for a years usage, after a year composers are paid depending on those many uses of their track. The only winner is the library who will retain 50% of the total license fee. It's exploitation.

For any user generated content platform, I don't believe anyone should be able to upload content without providing a license agreement to prove they have the rights to broadcast the music. 
No different to television, a brand can't just broadcast an advert with anyone's music without first obtaining a license from the rights holder.

column193: No, thank you. On a side note - I was unsettled to see Ditto flagged up, suggesting they are a reputable choice for distribution. Have a google of the complaints against them which are only the tip of the iceberg, backed up by the experiences of many people I know personally and professionally. Fortunately, I had good advice and was warned at the outset to avoid them, they are not a good organisation to be involved with and I'd be cautious of any implied endorsement. Their lack of professional integrity is another prime example of how vulnerable independent artists are to exploitation if they are naive and uneducated about the industry. There are many, many cases of artists being locked out of their income streams by Ditto for no good reason and they have no formal resolution procedures in place. I felt you should be aware of this.

column193:
The question about 'how important' streaming is to earning royalties doesn't really address the key issue, which is that it should be important to earning royalties because most people will now come into contact with and hear music via streaming services, but most people who listen on streaming services will not go on to purchase that music in another format, even if they stream it multiple times, add it to playlists, 'save' the album to their collection/profile etc.

However with revenue per stream from streaming services so low, that means that artists and labels operating at a low/mid-level do not earn enough to remotely survive.

I co-run a small independent record label and to give an example of the current situation with streaming income, the total number of streams across all artists on the label from Q2 2019 to Q4 2020 was 869,708. Corresponding earnings for almost 1 million streams was just £209.08, which equates at just £0.00024 per stream.

Once the distributor had taken their cut for processing and delivering to streaming services and stores, total earnings were £171.41, which equates to £0.00019 per stream.

I hope that this helps demonstrate that the present streaming model is fundamentally broken for all those but the most famous, highest-level artists, and the streaming companies themselves.

Streaming has saved the music industry. It's easier to make money from music than ever before, If you can't get 1 million streams, you could never have sold 1500 CDs either.. Not everyone who wants to will make a living from music, not everyone who wants to be a football player will become one, not everyone who wants to work for google gets a job. We need to stop the 'entitlement' and listening to the old men who were in bands when they were young and pine for the old days.

Also, as an independent artist, there are more options for getting investment / capital than ever before. If people sign stupid deals with major labels that's their own fault.

column193: For each single release, I spend about £300 on mixing and mastering and a further £200 on promotion (a rough estimate) which means I spend about £500 total. Via Bandcamp I might earn £100 of that spend back, on streaming services I can expect to earn no more than about £30 per year. This means that I am LOSING £350 or more per release. Say I were to release six singles in a year - that's over £2000 in losses that I can't reasonably avoid. My career doing something I don't want to do (e.g. working in a shop or office) funds the losses that I make in a career that I DO want to have. Help!

In my field (jazz / improvised music) there are not many fortunes to be made, but there is a loyal and committed audience, meaning that live revenue has always been possible, even in the UK where support for the arts and music is scant at best (my most profitable performing opportunities ALWAYS come from abroad, but now BREXIT has made this very difficult, even without the pandemic).
The proliferation of poorly remunerated streaming platforms means suddenly when live performance is curtailed as it has been in the last year, musicians like myself are struggling, and there is an enormous disparity between the cost of making recordings and the money it is possible to recoup. Major labels' monopoly of streaming services must be held to account to repair this broken system.

column193: My main issue (and reason for earning more now) is that I have begun teaching more now to make up for the lack of money the industry has to invest in musicians. I believe this is because streaming has made it difficult to earn revenue from sales because it's so grossly in favour of the consumer. SO overall I would say that my ability to exist primarily as an artist writing music has been overtaken by my need to take on other jobs (in my case teaching) to cover the shortfall. I have earned so very little from streaming, and have even found it difficult to reach audiences through streaming platforms like Spotify (again, it's beginning to seem like a "who you know" game to get your music on high-listener streaming playlists), so that I can't see its benefit. I also believe streaming has made it harder for independent labels to invest in band and now most of the onus (ie, recording, touring budget) is on the artist. The help just isn't there any more and I despair for younger artists starting out.

Most of my income as a writer/producer comes from royalties generated from works before streaming came about. I have stopped writing songs for pop acts now because the publishing paid from streaming is non existent now. I now self release work so that I can keep the masters as that's the only way to make any income from streaming but even then it's not guaranteed as the system doesn't necessarily reward and pay for the streams generated. It's very frustrating and has made it virtually impossible to make any real
Income from mew acts I work with.

column193: I have had massive difficulty with dealing with Ditto as a company. They have not withheld my online earnings and refuse to try and resolve this. I have had to resort to employing lawyers and they are still not conducting themselves in a professional manner to try and resolve the issues. I am totally shocked that companies are able to act in such a manner and take advantage of grassroot artists in this way. I hope that a investigating body looks into their misconduct as I have seen countless far to many other people online with the same issue as me with this company. All you have to do is search their reviews. This is criminal and should be treated that way.

column193: Streaming services like Spotify still need to do something about the songwriters as the present split doesn't seem fair - particularly when compared to radio. A usage centric payment model also seems to be the direction to go as everyone's monthly Spotify subscription significantly contributing to the payment of the top 100 artists vs say the 5 independent artists a user listened to on repeat for a year who get pennies of that annual subscription doesn't seem fair cop. It's also very difficult to get music to the ears of playlisters etc which is both opaque and something that only distributors have access to. Trying to get into the algorythm is chicken and egg as you need engagement in the first place which is difficult if your music is just sitting there. The streaming services have taken the place of magazines for music discovery but the whole experience has become passive for the user and barely penetrable - even with press and radio support, for the creators. And then if you are lucky enough to get sucked into the algorithm, there's little loyalty for next releases - I've seen 3 million streams for the lead single off a bands 2nd album in large part from playlists, followed by no playlisting of any tracks from the follow up album that fit the same brief causing the band to dissipate after streams in the thousands. This yeah I've gone from an incredibly busy previous year on various project, composing, producing, mixing, engineering and the most high profile release of my career, to half a days paid music work since the pandemic started and no support from any of the goverment self employed or music help schemes. The goal is trying to make amazing stuff and to share it with people to put something special, different, resonant and new into the world and this year has been soul destroying on that front and has lead to having to really question whether it's even worth trying to do this commercially and whether or not one is better off just doing something else for a living. This has massively effected my mental health this year and continues to do so. Art and music shouldn't be considered a luxury. It means so much to so many people and gives so much back to society/humanity as a whole. For independent artist and those trying to do something new and different which doesn't fit into the present wider commercial tracks - the present streaming model simply doesn't work.

column193:
I think streaming as an industry is great, however it should have had more attention when it swapped from Napster to more legitimate sites such as Spotify. There is no way people can expect musicians to be able to live off the amount streaming services pay out at the moment without the musician having another source of income. For someone who is only at the start of their journey in the industry, it is horrible to look at the way artists get mistreated and underpaid all for the sake of the middleman getting their cut.

I also believe streaming takes a lot of value away from music for people, as it's not something that people put as much thought into as they used to. For example, with the price of a Spotify subscription for a student (£5 a month) they would only be able to buy 1-2 records in the 80s or 90s and because of that, a lot more thought would have gone into what records that person is going to purchase and listen to. 

Whereas with streaming, paying such a small amount to have almost any song you want at the tap of a button - just gives it so much less value and thought. 

I'm not completely saying streaming should be banished, I just think the prices need to be raised significantly to make it more just for musicians and to help keep them motivated enough, knowing that one day they might be able to make a living off making and playing music. 

There is so much more I could say on this subject but I'm not going to over complicate it. 

Thank you for reading, and I hope the correct decisions are made to help musicians survive off their craft once again !

The per-stream rate for artists and composers is terrible, and will only lead to a creative drought as fewer people are able to survive as artists.

column193: It seems ridiculous that niche artists with devoted fans earn so little from streaming. It would be much better if Spotify pays royalties specific to each listener's consumption. EG if one listener only listens to one track once during their month's subscription, 100% of the artist/label royalty share should go to that artist/label. I think that Bjorn from Abba is arguing this point in an international convention. Before streaming, lots of niche artists could earn a living from selling a few thousand cds or vinyl, but this option is now impossible with Spotify. I would persuade my friends/fans to buy say 500 cds and make a small profit. But now how much do I make from their support? Enough for a cup of coffee if I am lucky. Youtube is much worse than Spotify. It is a massively profitable company yet their royalties are shockingly derisory.

column193: I may have misread the instruction for one of the pages which may not give a full picture. I can see the significance of 2015. That is the year I had to get a job that was outside of music. Up until that year I was making a fair living from music teaching, live events, playing shows and from sales of physical formats of music. Streaming has changed the landscape dramatically. It gives listeners access to millions of songs, cheaply and in a convenient app, and gives very little to the artist, financially.

column193:
As a society create data and we should be allowed to have some ownership over that data. 
If I listen and follow a band or artist on Spotify I want them to know that. I want them to be able to get in touch with me if I allow them to. Spotify and the big streaming services are the gate keepers to our customers. They use powerful tools to bring more people into their platforms and then allow them to use our music without us being able to properly use the data. 
Spotify have an artists area where you can look at data but it's not that useful, they say you can book tours by using the data but that's not true. 
Reason being that you can't discern between the listeners and followers data. Listens might just be in a Café and the happen to be hearing your music but nothing an actual fan. 
We as artist need access to our fans.

column193: I am preparing to record my own compositions for the first time, this year 2021.  I am going to use my savings to record music that I should have recorded during my life.  I am not sure how my 1st recording, using up to 50 musicians, in September, will be released or broadcast (I can find out) but will cost me up to £40,000. I had planned it as a CD but it looks as though it may only have digital release. I have no idea what this means for me, in terms of sales.  I have no publisher.  It is a big risk.  The 2nd recording, in November, will use 5 musicians and will be recorded by Meridian records.  Again, I have no idea how it will be released or broadcast.

column193: Steaming has becoming extremely important to growing an audience which is important for making a living from music, but the monetary return is so little that it is impossible for the average person to make a living from streaming.  We are working for almost nothing.  Streaming has actually destroyed all the ground work of trying to build a path to earing a living because it is now the industry standard to growing your audience.  Basically have to work for free.  You might get a larger audience but no money to show for it. It is very depressing and  demoralizing.  Steaming, as it is now, has harmed music creators significantly.

column193: Streaming has significantly affected physical sales of albums. As an independent artist, I make next to nothing from streams. There's no denying that streaming is how most people consume music these days, and artists more or less have to embrace this. The royalty rate paid out from streaming services is incredibly small, though - and I have read articles that suggest that the major labels have a stronghold on how royalties are distributed, receiving an unfair share of money for prospective streams. I feel that streaming services need tighter regulation, and should each embrace a more user-centric model of payment.

It's sad that you make no mention of CDs/vinyl/DVDs/etc., as if they no longer exist. Like many people, I still buy lots of them, but I have never bought a download/stream.

Perhaps the survey is focused on strea-mingers' serf-vices, but denying everything else is lame.
It is sad when even "research" is so biased and blinkered, but more about pushing an agenda.

column193:
I have always worked for labels in paralel to composing and being in bands and have actually worked on streaming for the past 7 years. I accept that there are an exponentially high number of artists self-releasing their music now compared to when I was in a signed band in 2004-2008, 'the pot' is much bigger than 10 years ago.
But streaming-only for small/medium sized bands isn't generating nearly enough earnings to just  break even, let alone pay rent or mortgage money!
In my unsigned bands up to 2010s, we could make enough money from a few gigs, selling CDs and merch, from bandcamp and itunes downloads, and a few syncs to keep going (as well as having a day job of course). We'd earn a few thousands each a year from it, enough to keep touring, rehearsing and recording new material. 
My issue is that now with streaming, only the biggest bands can reach sufficient scale and will be able to keep going. But many -  just as culturally valid artists - will struggle to keep going. Most of my artists friends in France can keep going because of State aid for artists and can at least  break even (with touring and sales) but it's getting harder there too with the loss of download income. They represent a very good indie Paris scene (The Rodeo, Mina Tindle, Jaune...). My fear is that without similar States aid in the UK, local indie scenes will disappear or be drowned within the 65k new tracks uploaded on Spotify each day. 
A lot of artists could get by with a few hundred/thousand sales, but won't ever be able to reach millions of streams. You could argue that 'only the best' bands will be able to keep going and that's always been the case to some extent (who gets signed back in the day) but there should be a better way for artists, composers and songwriters of all sizes to keep producing their art.
Artists that have managed to create a fanbase of a few thousands (hard enough to achieve) won't be able to keep going from streaming only instead of sales. There are alternatives that are positive (looking at you bandcamp!) but the more the better.

column193: The lack of income because of streaming has significantly impacted my confidence and motivation in creating music. My morale is at an all time low because despite having over 20 million streams, prestigious record label, award nominations, critical acclaim and a good following of fans I feel my work is of no value. I have sacrificed a huge amount in my life to make music with my band. I see other people earn money from the songs I've written (Spotify, record label, tour manager etc) whereas I earn practically nothing from the music I make. I'm unable to put enough time into music to get any further because I have to work other jobs to make ends meet. I feel like giving up at the peak of my career because I don't see a way that things can improve.

It really is a struggle to continue. It is not financially viable.

I would say that it can be difficult for actual independent artists (not with a label or publishing) to get funding for projects - sometimes taking two weeks to work on an application for grant made for new independent artists, to find out it goes to a label artist or someone relatively already established with backing and contacts at certain artist funding companies - it can often be better trying to earn that money yourself, the only downside of course being it can take a lot longer to do so.

I think it would also be great if Apple began a pitching service via distributors, similarly to the Spotify For Artists one.

column193: I think streaming platforms should pay artists a better percentage, we deserve it as without us they don't have a business. I would also like them to be more transparent and to do more to help artists build a fanbase. I have no way of contacting my followers, I would like to know who they are in the same way I do on twitter for instance. I would like more control. I also think Artists should at least get a discount on membership of Apple and SPOTIFY.... I don't make the amount in Spotify royalties that Spotify charge for one month's membership in one year! Unbelievable, isn't it?

column193: Yes - my band signed a record deal in 2011. Our first album did ok. We were on course to pay back our advance. Our second record came out in 2013 and again it did ok, but this time more money was spent on us and we didnt manage pay our advance back. Both of those records sold more physical than streams. Streaming wasnt really part of the equation then. So there was a huge amount riding on the third album. The third album - physical sales weren't great, but the streaming figures were amazing, one of the tracks got 4 million spins, our shows were packing out, lots of people saying they'd discovered us via Spotify - everyone was saying the record was a success. When the statements came in, because the physical was so bad we made absolutely zero £££'s on that record and now our debt to the record label is so vast we are in a hole. That third record, though increasing our fanbase, meant we had to put the band on hold for 3 years while we all worked out how to survive financially, which from a career point of view could have been a total disaster. Our fourth album came out in 2020 and we have been very lucky. But as I type this, my band has had over 25 million streams since 2015, a Mercury Music Prize shortlisted album (2020), and yet we dont seem to have made any significant money from any of it. I cant understand that.

column193:
The music industry is broken, the tech companies have bullied the few remaining record companies into a corner and the record companies blinked first. 
The result,... artists, producers, engineers can no longer earn realistic income to sustain a career in the industry.
